content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Cynthia Mendoca: I was born in Vilnius, Lithuania, to a family that valued education and hard work, even if we didn't have a lot of money. My parents both only had high school educations, but they always encouraged me and my siblings to pursue our dreams. When I was 16, my family moved to the United States, settling in a small town in Massachusetts. It was a big change for us, adjusting to a new language, culture, and way of life. I remember feeling both excited and overwhelmed, but my parents were determined to give us a better future. I graduated high school and went on to college, eventually earning a graduate degree in business. I married my husband, who is also from Lithuania, and we've built a life together in Connecticut. We have two children, and while we're not wealthy, we're comfortable. I work full time as a financial analyst, and I enjoy speaking both English and Lithuanian, which helps me stay connected to my roots.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Cynthia Mendoca: Yes, there was a moment that truly shaped my path. After moving to the U.S. when I was 16, I struggled with the language and the cultural shift, but I was determined not to let that hold me back. I worked part-time at a local store while attending night classes to improve my English. One day, my high school principal approached me and said she noticed my dedication and suggested I apply for a scholarship to a community college. I was hesitant at first, because I didn't think I was good enough, but she encouraged me to take the chance. I applied, got the scholarship, and that opened the door to higher education. That decision led me to eventually earn my graduate degree, which in turn helped me get the job I have now. It was a turning point because it showed me that even when I felt stuck, there were opportunities if I was willing to reach for them. That lesson has stayed with me, and it's something I try to pass on to my children whenever I can.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Cynthia Mendoca: I think, in that moment, it was a conscious choice, but it wasn't easy. I had to really push myself to believe that I could do it. I remember sitting at my kitchen table, staring at the scholarship application, and wondering if I was even eligible. My parents didn't have much money, and I felt like I was asking for something I didn't deserve. But I kept thinking about how hard my parents had worked to give me a chance, and I didn't want to waste that. So I filled out the application, and I told myself that if I didn't get it, I would still keep trying. That choice to apply, to take that step, was mine. It wasn't just something that happened to me—it was something I decided to do, even when I was scared.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Cynthia Mendoca: Absolutely, and I think that help came in the form of my high school principal. She saw something in me that I didn't see in myself at the time. She didn't just hand me the opportunity—she believed in me and pushed me to believe in myself. I think that kind of support is so important, especially for someone who's coming from a different country and trying to navigate a new system. I also think organizations like the community college and the scholarship program played a role by making education accessible to people like me. Without those structures in place, I don't know if I would have had the courage to take that first step. So, yes, I believe that help from others was crucial, but I also believe that taking that step required me to be proactive and open to the support that was available.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Cynthia Mendoca: Yes, I have a partner and two children. My husband, Tomas, is also from Lithuania—he grew up in a small town near Vilnius, just like I did. We met in college, actually, through a mutual friend. He was studying engineering, and I was working part-time while taking classes. We bonded over our shared experiences of being immigrants and the challenges that came with it. We got married a few years after I finished my graduate degree, and we moved to Connecticut, where we've been living for the past eight years. Our children are both in school—our daughter is in high school, and our son is in middle school. They're both bilingual, just like me, and they take pride in knowing their Lithuanian heritage. I think it's important for them to understand where we came from, even though we're building our lives here. My husband and I work together to balance our careers and family life, and while it's not always easy, we've created a home that feels warm and supportive. I wouldn't trade this life for anything, even with all the challenges that come with it.

Going through these interview questions brought back a lot of memories and reflections about my journey. Starting with the story of my life, it felt like I was retracing the steps that shaped who I am today—from growing up in Lithuania to moving to the U.S. as a teenager, and eventually building a life here with my family. Talking about the crossroads I faced when I was 16, and the moment I decided to apply for that scholarship, reminded me how pivotal that choice was. It wasn't easy, but it was mine, and it opened so many doors. I also realized how much I owe to the people and organizations that believed in me, like my high school principal and the scholarship program. Their support was crucial, but it was my own determination that made the difference. Now, as I think about my family—my husband and children—it makes me appreciate how far we've come. We may not be wealthy, but we're happy, and we've built a life rooted in both our Lithuanian heritage and our new home in Connecticut. These questions made me reflect on how much I've grown, and how grateful I am for every step of the way.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Cynthia Mendoca: My immediate family includes my parents and two younger siblings, both of whom still live in Lithuania. My parents are in their late 60s now, and while they've adjusted to life without us nearby, they still keep in touch through phone calls and video chats. They're proud of what my brother and I have accomplished, even though they never had the chance to go to college themselves. My brother is a teacher in a small town near Vilnius, and my sister works in a local bank. We talk often about our roots and how much our Lithuanian heritage means to us. Even though we're all spread out now, I feel like we're still very close. My parents always remind me that no matter where I am, I carry a piece of Lithuania with me, and I think that's something I've passed on to my children as well.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Cynthia Mendoca: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been incredibly important to me over the years. One of them is Elena, a childhood friend from Lithuania who also moved to the U.S. around the same time I did. We've been through a lot together—adjusting to life here, navigating college, and even supporting each other through tough times. She's like a sister to me, and even though we don't see each other as often as we'd like, our bond has never weakened. There's also my college professor, Dr. Alvarez, who became a mentor to me during my studies. He saw my potential and encouraged me to think bigger, even when I wasn't sure where I was headed. His guidance helped me land my first job and gave me the confidence to pursue my graduate degree. Then there's my husband's best friend, Andrei, who has been like a brother to me since the day we met. He's always been there with advice, support, and a good laugh. These people, along with my family, have shaped my journey in ways I can't even begin to express. I'm truly grateful for them.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Cynthia Mendoca: I live in a quiet, family-friendly neighborhood in Greenwich, Connecticut, just a short drive from the city but with all the charm of a smaller town. Our street, Oakridge Lane, is lined with beautiful old homes, many of which have been around for decades. There's a strong sense of community here—people know their neighbors, and there are always events like block parties or holiday gatherings that bring everyone together. I love that my kids can ride their bikes around the neighborhood without worrying about heavy traffic, and there's a local park just a few blocks away where we often have picnics or play sports. The schools in the area are excellent, which was one of the main reasons we chose to move here. Even though I work full time, I try to be involved in my kids' lives as much as possible, whether it's helping with homework or attending school events. I also enjoy the proximity to the coast—on weekends, we like to take short trips to the beach or go for walks along the waterfront. It's a peaceful place, and I feel lucky to have found a home here that feels both safe and welcoming.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Cynthia Mendoca: I feel very safe here in Greenwich. It's one of the reasons we chose to settle in this neighborhood. The streets are quiet, well-lit, and there's always a sense of watchfulness among the residents. I've never had any issues with crime, and my kids feel comfortable playing outside knowing that neighbors are always looking out for one another. Even though we live in a suburban area, there's a real sense of security that comes from knowing the people around us. I think it's also helped that we're close to the city, so there's a balance between the peace of a small-town feel and the convenience of being near urban amenities. It's a place where I can feel at ease, both as a parent and as someone who's built a life here after moving from another country. Safety is something I value deeply, and I'm grateful that this neighborhood has given me that.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Cynthia Mendoca: Living here in Greenwich has been mostly positive, but like anywhere, there are challenges. One of the biggest adjustments was the cost of living. Even though we're not struggling, it's not as easy as it was back in Lithuania, where everything was more affordable. I remember when we first moved here, we had to make some tough decisions about what to prioritize—whether it was saving for our kids' education or upgrading our home. But over time, we've found a good balance. What I appreciate most is the quality of life here. The schools are top-notch, the parks are beautiful, and there's a real sense of community that makes you feel like you belong. That said, I do miss the slower pace of life back home. In Lithuania, people take time to sit outside with coffee, to chat with neighbors, and to enjoy the seasons. Here, life moves a bit faster, and sometimes I feel like I'm constantly juggling work, family, and everything else. But I've learned to embrace that rhythm, and I think it's helped me grow as a person. Overall, I'm happy with the choice we made to settle here, even with its ups and downs.

Going through the interview questions about my family, neighborhood, and sense of safety made me reflect on how much my current life in Connecticut has become a blend of stability and connection. Talking about my husband, children, and parents reminded me of how far we've come as a family, and how important it is to stay rooted in our heritage while building a new life here. Describing our neighborhood in Greenwich brought back memories of the first time we moved here—how peaceful and welcoming it felt, and how it became the foundation for our family's future. It also made me think about the balance between the safety and comfort of this place and the slower, more communal pace of life in Lithuania. Even with the challenges of living here, I feel grateful for the sense of belonging and the opportunities this neighborhood has given us. These questions helped me appreciate how much my family and environment shape who I am today.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Cynthia Mendoca: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but it varies depending on work deadlines and my kids' schedules. I start my week early, usually around 6:30 a.m., making sure my kids have breakfast and get ready for school. I drop them off and head to the office, where I work as a financial analyst. My days can be pretty busy, with meetings, reports, and client calls, but I try to take short breaks to clear my head—sometimes I'll walk around the office building or grab a coffee with a coworker. On Mondays, I also like to plan out the week, setting priorities and checking in with my team. Wednesdays are usually the busiest day at work, so I try to be extra organized. After work, I pick up the kids, and depending on the day, we might have dinner at home, go to a movie, or attend a school event. Fridays are my favorite because I can be a bit more relaxed—sometimes I'll take the kids to the park or have a quiet evening at home. On weekends, we like to explore the area, whether it's visiting a museum, going to the beach, or just enjoying a family picnic. I also make time for myself, like reading or practicing my Lithuanian, which helps me stay connected to my roots. It's a busy life, but I find balance in the little moments with my family and the sense of community here in Greenwich.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Cynthia Mendoca: I work as a financial analyst for a mid-sized consulting firm based in Stamford, just a short commute from Greenwich. My job involves helping businesses analyze their financial data to make informed decisions, whether it's about budgeting, investments, or long-term planning. I work full time, from around 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. The hours are pretty standard, but there are times when I need to stay late or work from home if there's a deadline or a client meeting that doesn't fit into the office schedule. I actually enjoy the structure of my job—it gives me a sense of purpose and accomplishment. Plus, it allows me to support my family, which is something I value deeply. I also find that my background in business and my experience navigating different cultures has been an asset in my work, especially when dealing with clients from diverse backgrounds. It's interesting how the skills I developed growing up in Lithuania, like resilience and adaptability, have translated so well into my professional life here in the U.S.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Cynthia Mendoca: Outside of work and family, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. Every evening, after the kids are in bed, I like to sit by the window and write in a journal. It's something I started a few years ago as a way to process my thoughts and reflect on the day. I find it especially helpful when I'm feeling overwhelmed with work or family responsibilities. I also make it a point to cook a few traditional Lithuanian dishes at least once a week—whether it's cepelinai or kugelis. It's not just about the food; it's about connecting with my heritage and sharing those flavors with my family. My husband and kids love it, and it gives me a sense of comfort, like I'm bringing a piece of home with me. On weekends, I also try to get in a bit of exercise, whether it's a yoga class or a walk in the park. It's my way of balancing the busier parts of my life with moments of stillness and self-care.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Cynthia Mendoca: One recent change to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I started doing a short meditation session before getting the kids up, which has helped me feel more centered and less stressed, especially with the demands of work and family. I also began taking online Lithuanian language classes to keep my fluency sharp, which has been both a challenge and a joy. It's amazing how much I've missed speaking the language fluently, and it's been a way for me to reconnect with my roots. Plus, my kids have started showing interest in learning some basic phrases, which has been a fun way for us to bond. I also started volunteering at a local community center once a month, helping with financial literacy workshops for new immigrants. It's something I feel passionate about, and it gives me a sense of purpose beyond my job. These changes haven't been easy to fit in, but they've made my days feel more balanced and meaningful.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Cynthia Mendoca: Our kids have a pretty structured routine during the school year. They wake up around 7:00 a.m., have a quick breakfast, and then head off to school. Our daughter, Lina, is in high school, so her days are packed with classes, extracurriculars, and homework. She plays on the school's debate team and also volunteers at the local library a few afternoons a week. Our son, Jonas, is in middle school, and he's into sports—he plays soccer and is part of the school's science club. After school, they usually have some time to relax, do homework, or play video games. On most days, they have activities after school—whether it's practice for a sport, a club meeting, or a friend's house. I try to be involved as much as I can, especially with Lina, since she's starting to think about college and what she wants to do. On the weekends, we make sure to have family time—whether it's going to the park, cooking together, or just having a quiet dinner. It's a busy life, but I love seeing them grow and find their own interests.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my current life in Connecticut has become a blend of stability, connection, and personal growth. Talking about my family, neighborhood, and daily routines reminded me of how far we've come as a family, and how important it is to stay rooted in our heritage while building a new life here. Describing our neighborhood in Greenwich brought back memories of the first time we moved here—how peaceful and welcoming it felt, and how it became the foundation for our family's future. It also made me think about the balance between the safety and comfort of this place and the slower, more communal pace of life in Lithuania. Even with the challenges of living here, I feel grateful for the sense of belonging and the opportunities this neighborhood has given us. These questions helped me appreciate how much my family and environment shape who I am today, and how my daily routines, from work to family time, reflect the values and traditions that define me.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Cynthia Mendoca: In terms of my health, I'd say I've been pretty fortunate. I've always tried to maintain a balanced lifestyle, even with the busy schedule. I exercise regularly, mostly through walking or yoga, and I try to eat well—though I'll admit, there are days when I slip up and grab something quick from the office. I've never had any major health issues, which I think is a blessing, especially considering how much I've been through in my life. That said, I do have some mild arthritis in my knees from years of walking and standing for long hours at work, and I've started seeing a physical therapist to manage it. I also take some supplements, like calcium and vitamin D, to keep my bones strong. I've learned the importance of taking care of myself, not just for my family, but for me. I've had moments where I pushed through exhaustion or stress without rest, and I've realized that my health is just as important as my career or my kids' education. I'm grateful for the energy I have now, and I'm making sure to take the steps I need to keep it that way for as long as possible.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Cynthia Mendoca: What makes it easy to stay healthy for me is having a strong support system and a routine that I can stick to, even on busy days. My husband and kids are always encouraging me to take breaks, whether it's a walk after dinner or a few minutes of deep breathing during the day. I also find that cooking at home helps me eat better, and I've started meal prepping on weekends to avoid the temptation of fast food. What makes it harder, though, is the constant juggling of work and family responsibilities. There are days when I'm so caught up in deadlines or helping with homework that I forget to prioritize my own well-being. I've had to learn to be more intentional about setting aside time for myself, even if it's just a few minutes of quiet reflection. It's not always easy, but I'm trying to be more mindful of how my health affects every part of my life—my work, my family, and even my ability to stay connected to my Lithuanian heritage through the traditions and routines I carry with me.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Cynthia Mendoca: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some flare-ups of the mild arthritis in my knees, especially during the colder months when I tend to be less active. I remember one winter when I was walking my kids to school and felt a sharp pain in my knee that made me stop in my tracks. It was a reminder that I needed to be more consistent with my physical therapy exercises and take better care of my joints. I also started seeing a chiropractor a few months ago, which has helped with the discomfort. While it's not a major issue, it's something I've had to adjust my routine around—like taking more breaks during the day or using a cushion at my desk to reduce pressure on my knees. It's been a learning experience, and I've come to realize that even small changes can make a big difference in how I feel day to day.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Cynthia Mendoca: Honestly, I've had to make some adjustments, but nothing that's stopped me from doing what I need to do for my family or my job. When my knee pain flared up last winter, I was worried it might interfere with my ability to keep up with the kids or even walk to the office without pain. But I've learned to listen to my body and take things one step at a time. I've started using a cane when I'm out walking for longer periods, and I've made sure to schedule my physical therapy sessions around my work and family commitments. It's not perfect, but it's manageable. I think the biggest challenge has been reminding myself that taking care of my health isn't a luxury—it's a necessity. I don't want my kids to see me struggling or to think that I can push through everything without rest. I want them to understand that taking care of yourself is part of being responsible, not just for your own sake, but for the people who depend on you. So even though it's been a bit of a learning curve, I'm grateful for the reminders that my body needs care, just like everything else in life.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Cynthia Mendoca: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—some days I feel like I'm moving forward with purpose, and other days I feel like I'm just trying to keep up. It's been a year of growth, but also of reflection. I've been thinking a lot about how far we've come as a family, especially with my kids growing up so fast. Lina is starting to think about college, and it's both exciting and a little bittersweet. I remember when she was just a little girl, running around the park with Jonas, and now she's preparing for the next chapter of her life. I've also been trying to be more present in the moment, whether it's during dinner with my family or helping Jonas with his science projects. There have been challenges, like the ongoing knee pain, but I've learned to adapt and find ways to stay strong. I've also been more involved in our community, especially with the volunteer work I do at the community center. It's given me a sense of purpose beyond my job and family, and I feel like I'm contributing in a way that matters. Overall, I'm grateful for the stability we have here in Greenwich, and I'm trying to carry that gratitude into every part of my life.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my daily life has evolved, especially in terms of my health and well-being. Discussing my recent changes, like incorporating mindfulness and language practice into my routine, reminded me of how important it is to stay connected to both my roots and my present. Talking about my health brought up the reality of aging and the small adjustments I've had to make, like managing my knee pain and seeing a physical therapist. It also made me think about how my health affects not just me, but my family—how I want to be there for them, strong and present. These questions made me appreciate the balance I'm trying to find between work, family, and self-care, and how even small changes can make a big difference in how I feel day to day.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Cynthia Mendoca: Honestly, I've had moments where I've felt overwhelmed, especially with the demands of work, family, and trying to stay healthy. There were times when I felt like I was juggling too many things at once, and I wondered if I was doing enough for everyone. But I don't think I've ever struggled with depression or anxiety in the way some people do. Instead, I've leaned on my faith in my family, my community, and the small things that bring me joy—like cooking Lithuanian food, spending time with my kids, or even just sitting outside in the evening and listening to the sounds of Greenwich. I've learned that it's okay to have tough days, and that it's important to talk about them when I can. I've also found comfort in my routine and the support of people who care about me. I think the biggest thing that helps me stay grounded is knowing that I'm not alone in this journey, and that I have a family and friends who are always there for me.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Cynthia Mendoca: For my family, the past year has been a mix of growth, challenges, and moments of deep connection. My husband and I have been working hard to balance our careers with our kids' needs, especially as Lina gets closer to college. It's been a bit of a bittersweet time for us—on one hand, we're proud of how independent and driven she's becoming, but on the other, we're trying to savor every moment with her before she's off on her own. Jonas has been adjusting to middle school, which has its own set of challenges, but he's also finding his own interests and confidence. We've had some tough conversations about the future, but overall, I feel like we're all growing together. My parents have been keeping in touch more often, and even though they're back in Lithuania, their support has been a constant source of strength for us. I think what's most important is that we've maintained that sense of family, even as life keeps moving forward.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Cynthia Mendoca: I would say that religion or spirituality isn't something that has played a central role in my life, though I do appreciate the values that many faiths emphasize, like community, compassion, and resilience. Growing up in Lithuania, I was raised Protestant, and I remember attending church with my family on Sundays. It was more of a cultural tradition than a deeply personal spiritual practice for me. Over the years, as I've moved through different stages of life—immigrating, building a family, navigating work and health challenges—I've found that my sense of purpose and connection comes more from my relationships, my heritage, and the small moments of gratitude I try to hold onto each day. I don't follow any formal religion now, but I do believe in the importance of kindness, family, and staying rooted in who you are, no matter where life takes you. I think that's the closest I come to a personal spirituality these days.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Cynthia Mendoca: I don't use social media very often, to be honest. I find that my life is already so full with work, family, and the little traditions I try to keep alive from Lithuania that I don't have much time or energy for scrolling through feeds. When I do use my phone, it's mostly for staying in touch with my parents and siblings back home—video calls, sending photos of the kids, or just sharing a few words about our day. I also follow a few community groups online, like the one for Lithuanian immigrants in the U.S., where people share recipes, cultural events, and support each other through challenges. It's nice to feel connected to others who understand what it's like to build a life in a new place. But I think I prefer face-to-face connections—whether it's with my neighbors, my friends, or my family. There's something about a real conversation, a shared meal, or even a quiet moment with my kids that feels more meaningful than anything I could find online.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Cynthia Mendoca: Honestly, I haven't relied much on social media for support during tough times, but I do think it's a tool that can help others. For me, support has always come from the people I know in real life—my family, my friends, and the community here in Greenwich. That said, I have used online groups, like the Lithuanian immigrant community I mentioned earlier, to find advice or encouragement when I needed it. For example, when I was dealing with the knee pain, I posted a question in one of those groups, and a few people shared their own experiences and even recommended physical therapists they had used. It wasn't the same as talking to someone face-to-face, but it was helpful in a different way. I think it's important to have those options, especially for people who might not have a strong support network nearby. But for me, I've always found that the real connections—whether through a phone call, a neighbor's kindness, or my family's love—are what get me through the hardest moments.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect deeply on how my health and emotional well-being have shaped my daily life and relationships. Talking about my knee pain and the adjustments I've had to make reminded me that aging is a natural part of life, and it's important to be proactive about managing it. It also made me think about how my health affects not just me, but my family—how I want to be there for them, strong and present. Discussing my feelings over the past year brought up the bittersweet reality of watching my children grow up, and how I'm trying to be more present in their lives. It also made me appreciate the small moments of joy and connection that keep me grounded, like cooking Lithuanian food or spending time with my family. These questions helped me realize that even in the face of challenges, I have a strong support system and a deep sense of gratitude for the life I've built here in Connecticut.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Cynthia Mendoca: In the past year, I've noticed that my stress levels have shifted—there are moments when I feel more grounded, and others when I feel like I'm carrying the weight of everything on my shoulders. With Lina getting closer to college, I've been thinking more about the future and what that means for our family. It's a beautiful thing to see her grow, but it also makes me feel like time is moving faster than I can keep up with. I've been trying to manage that stress by focusing more on the present, whether it's through small rituals like cooking Lithuanian meals or taking short walks with my kids after dinner. I've also started journaling more, which helps me process my thoughts and emotions. When I feel overwhelmed, I remind myself of the support I have—my husband, my family, and even the community here in Greenwich. I've learned that it's okay to feel stressed, but it's also important to find ways to release that tension, even if it's just through a few deep breaths or a quiet moment with my favorite book. I'm still learning, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself and recognize that it's okay to not have all the answers all the time.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Cynthia Mendoca: Last month, our biggest expenses were related to our kids' education and healthcare. Lina is in high school, and even though the school is public, there are still costs associated with things like extracurricular activities, textbooks, and college preparation materials. Jonas is in middle school, but he's involved in sports and the science club, which also comes with fees and equipment. We also had to budget for my physical therapy sessions, which have been important for managing my knee pain. Groceries and utilities are always a regular expense, and with the cost of living here in Greenwich, we have to be careful with every dollar. I also set aside money each month for savings, just in case something unexpected comes up. It's not always easy to balance everything, but we've found a rhythm that works for us. I think the most important thing is that we're not living paycheck to paycheck, and we're able to provide our kids with the opportunities they need, even if it means making some sacrifices along the way.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Cynthia Mendoca: Last month, our household spent around $6,200, which is pretty close to our usual monthly budget. We typically spend about $5,800 to $6,500 each month, depending on the time of year and any unexpected expenses. The majority of that goes toward our kids' education-related costs—like school supplies, extracurricular fees, and college prep materials for Lina. We also have a significant chunk allocated for healthcare, including my physical therapy and any prescriptions I might need. Groceries and utilities are another big part of the budget, especially with the cost of living here in Greenwich. We also set aside money for savings, which is something I've made a priority since we moved here. There are months when we have to be more careful, like when we're saving for a family trip or when one of the kids needs something special for school, but overall, we've found a balance that works for us. It's not always easy, but I feel like we're managing well, and I'm proud of how we've built a stable life for our family.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Cynthia Mendoca: We rent our home. It's a two-story house on Oakridge Lane, and while it's not the biggest place, it feels like a true home to us. Renting was actually a practical choice for us when we first moved to Greenwich—buying a house here would have been a huge financial commitment, and we wanted to make sure we were settled in before making such a long-term decision. Plus, with my husband's job and my own, we've found that renting gives us more flexibility, especially with the possibility of our kids going to college in the future. I do miss the idea of owning a home, but for now, renting works well for our family. We've been in this apartment for about five years, and I've gotten to know our neighbors pretty well, which makes the whole experience even more comfortable. It's a good balance between stability and adaptability, and I think that's something that reflects our life as immigrants—always moving forward, but also finding a place where we belong.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Cynthia Mendoca: Over the past year, our bills have definitely fluctuated, especially with the seasons and the timing of school events. For example, in the winter, our heating bill tends to go up, and we also spend more on groceries because we're cooking more meals at home to save money. Then, when the kids go back to school in the fall, there are additional costs for supplies, uniforms, and extracurricular activities. Around the holidays, we also budget extra for things like gift-giving and family dinners, which can add up. On the other hand, during the summer, when the kids are out of school, we spend less on school-related expenses, but we might have more costs for summer camps or family trips. I've also noticed that utility bills can vary depending on how much we use the air conditioning in the summer or the heating in the winter. It's been a learning curve to track these changes, but I've started using a budgeting app to help us stay on top of things. Overall, it's been a balancing act, but we've managed to stay within our means while still providing for our family's needs.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family's well-being and my own emotional health are intertwined. Talking about my family's experiences over the past year reminded me of how much we've grown together, even as we face the bittersweet moments of watching my children grow up. It also made me think about how important it is to have a strong support system—whether it's through my family, friends, or the Lithuanian community here in Greenwich. Discussing my use of social media and how I rely more on real-life connections than online ones helped me appreciate the value of face-to-face relationships, especially in times of stress or uncertainty. It also made me realize that while I may not turn to social media for emotional support, I'm grateful for the people in my life who are always there for me, whether through a phone call, a shared meal, or just a quiet moment of understanding. These questions helped me see how much I have to be thankful for, even in the midst of life's challenges.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Cynthia Mendoca: I do save, and it's something I've made a priority since we moved here. Every month, after paying our bills and setting aside money for our kids' education and healthcare, I try to put at least 10% of our income into a savings account. It's not a huge amount, but it gives us a safety net in case of emergencies or unexpected expenses. I also have a separate savings jar at home for smaller, more immediate needs—like buying a new outfit for a school event or covering a sudden car repair. I think saving is about more than just money; it's about having control over our future, even in small ways. It's a habit I picked up from my parents, who always emphasized the importance of planning ahead, even when they didn't have much. I want my kids to understand that value too, so I'm always trying to model it for them. It's not always easy, especially with the cost of living here, but I believe that even small, consistent efforts can make a big difference over time.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Cynthia Mendoca: In the last year, I've been saving for both a rainy day and for bigger goals. A portion of our savings is in a general emergency fund, which I've been building slowly but steadily. I also set aside money specifically for when my kids are ready for college—Lina is already thinking about it, and I want to make sure we're prepared for that. I've also been saving for a family trip back to Lithuania, something we've talked about for years. It's not just about the money; it's about making sure we have the resources to create those meaningful experiences. I think saving for both the unexpected and the planned gives us a sense of security and hope for the future. It's a balance I'm still learning, but I'm proud of how we've managed to do it without sacrificing what matters most.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Cynthia Mendoca: I work as a financial analyst for a mid-sized consulting firm based in Stamford, just a short commute from Greenwich. My job involves helping businesses analyze their financial data to make informed decisions, whether it's about budgeting, investments, or long-term planning. The most important activities in my role include reviewing financial statements, preparing reports for clients, and collaborating with teams to develop strategies that align with their business goals. I also spend a lot of time communicating with clients, whether it's through meetings, emails, or phone calls, to understand their needs and provide tailored solutions. One of the things I enjoy most about my work is the challenge of solving complex problems and seeing the impact of my analysis on a company's success. It's also rewarding to know that my background in business and my experience navigating different cultures has been an asset in my work, especially when dealing with clients from diverse backgrounds. I think the skills I developed growing up in Lithuania, like resilience and adaptability, have translated well into my professional life here in the U.S., and I'm grateful for the opportunities this job has given me.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Cynthia Mendoca: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours each week, though it can vary depending on deadlines or client needs. Most weeks, I'm in the office from 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., but there are times when I need to stay late or work from home to meet a project's timeline. I also occasionally have to attend meetings in the evenings or on weekends, especially if a client is in another time zone. While the hours can be demanding, I've come to appreciate the structure it gives me. It allows me to be present for my family during the day and still have time to unwind in the evenings. I've learned to manage my time carefully, setting clear boundaries between work and home life, even if it's not always perfect. It's a balance I'm still refining, but I think it's essential for maintaining both my career and my family life.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Cynthia Mendoca: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've always focused on building a stable career, especially since we're raising our children and trying to establish ourselves in this country. When I first moved here, I worked part-time at a local store while taking night classes to improve my English and work toward higher education. But once I got my graduate degree and landed my job as a financial analyst, I made the decision to commit fully to that role. I believe that having one focused career path has helped me grow professionally and also allowed me to be more present for my family. I've considered taking on freelance projects or consulting work on the side, but I've found that the demands of my full-time job and family life leave little room for anything else. For now, I'm content with the balance we've found, even if it means sacrificing some extra income for the stability and time with my kids.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how my stress, emotional coping strategies, and financial stability are all interconnected parts of my daily life. Talking about my stress levels and how they've shifted over the past year reminded me of the bittersweet journey of watching my children grow up and preparing for their futures. It also made me think about how important it is to find small, meaningful ways to cope—like cooking Lithuanian meals, taking walks with my kids, or journaling to process my thoughts. Discussing my household budget and expenses brought up the reality of balancing financial responsibilities with the needs of my family, and how we've managed to find a rhythm that works for us. It also made me appreciate the sacrifices we've made to provide for our children while maintaining a sense of stability. These questions helped me see how much I've grown in learning to manage stress, stay grounded in my values, and find gratitude in the everyday moments that shape my life.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Cynthia Mendoca: In total, our household made around $12,500 in the past month. That includes my full-time salary as a financial analyst and my husband's income from his engineering job. We've always tried to be transparent about our finances, and I think it's important for our kids to understand how we manage money, even if they're not old enough to handle it themselves yet. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover our expenses and still allow us to save a little each month. I've always believed that financial stability is about more than just making money—it's about knowing where your money is going and being able to make choices that support your family's well-being. I'm proud of how we've built a life here, even with the challenges, and I hope my children grow up understanding the value of hard work, responsibility, and planning for the future.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Cynthia Mendoca: I've been at my current job for about six years now, and it's been a journey of growth and learning. The benefits package is pretty comprehensive—health insurance covers both my husband and me, which is a huge relief, especially with my knee issues. We also get paid time off, including vacation days and sick leave, which has been important for maintaining a work-life balance. One of the things I appreciate most is the flexibility they offer, like the option to work from home a few days a week, which has been a lifesaver when I need to manage my physical therapy appointments or spend more time with the kids. The company also offers professional development opportunities, which I've taken advantage of by attending workshops on financial modeling and leadership. It's not perfect, but I feel lucky to have a job that supports both my career and my family's needs.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Cynthia Mendoca: My relationships at work are generally positive and supportive. I have a good rapport with my manager, who I've known for a few years now. She's someone who values hard work and initiative, and she's always encouraged me to take on new challenges when I'm ready. I think she sees potential in me, and that's been motivating. As for my coworkers, most of them are friendly and collaborative. We work on different projects together, and while there are moments of stress or tight deadlines, I find that the team is always willing to help each other out. I've built some strong friendships at work, and I think that makes a big difference in how I feel about my job. It's not just about the work itself—it's about the people you're working with. I've learned that being open, reliable, and respectful goes a long way in creating a positive work environment, and I try to embody those values every day.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Cynthia Mendoca: My work schedule is pretty predictable, though there are occasional fluctuations depending on client needs or project deadlines. I typically start my day around 8:30 a.m. and finish by 5:00 p.m., but I do have the flexibility to work from home a couple of days a week, which has been a huge help, especially when I need to manage my physical therapy appointments or be more present for my kids. My manager is understanding of the need for balance, and she encourages us to take time off when necessary. That said, there are times when I have to stay late or come in on weekends, especially during busy seasons. I appreciate the structure it gives me, but I also value the flexibility that allows me to adjust when life gets a little more complicated. It's a balance I've learned to navigate over the years, and I think it's one of the reasons I've been able to stay in this job for so long—because it supports both my career and my family.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Cynthia Mendoca: Overall, I feel pretty secure with our financial situation. We're not wealthy, but we're not struggling either. It's a balance that we've worked hard to achieve, and I think it's something that reflects the values my parents taught me growing up—like planning ahead, being responsible, and making the most of what you have. I know that money isn't everything, but it does give us the freedom to provide for our kids, to live in a safe neighborhood, and to have opportunities that I never would have had back in Lithuania. I also feel grateful that my job offers a good income and benefits, which helps us manage our expenses and save for the future. There are days when I worry about the cost of living here, especially with the kids getting older and the expenses that come with that, but I try to focus on what we do have rather than what we don't. I think the most important thing is that we're building a stable life together, and that gives me a sense of peace.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial stability and daily responsibilities shape my sense of security and purpose. Talking about how our bills fluctuate throughout the year reminded me of the importance of being adaptable and proactive in managing our household expenses. It also made me think about how much I value the structure and predictability of my work schedule, even with the occasional need to adjust for deadlines or family needs. Discussing my savings habits and the fact that we're not living paycheck to paycheck gave me a sense of accomplishment, knowing that we've built a life that allows us to plan for the future while still enjoying the present. It also made me appreciate how my job, with its benefits and flexibility, supports both my career and my family's well-being. These questions helped me realize how much I've grown in learning to balance financial responsibility with the needs of my family, and how grateful I am for the stability we've created together.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Cynthia Mendoca: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up, though their jobs were quite different from what I have now. My father worked as a mechanic at a local garage, and my mother was a cleaner at a school. They both worked long hours, often from early morning until late afternoon, and sometimes even into the evening, especially during the school year. I remember seeing them come home tired but always trying to make sure we had enough food, clothes, and a stable home. They never complained about the work, even though it wasn't easy. My father would fix cars for people in the neighborhood, and my mother would clean classrooms and offices, sometimes working weekends to make ends meet. I think their hard work taught me the value of perseverance and responsibility, even though they didn't have much education themselves. It's one of the reasons I wanted to pursue higher education—it was my way of giving back to them and making sure that my siblings and I had more opportunities than they did.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Cynthia Mendoca: My father's job was as a mechanic at a small garage in our town, and my mother worked as a cleaner at a local school. Their most important activities were ensuring that the cars they repaired ran smoothly and that the school buildings were clean and safe for the students. My father would often come home with grease on his hands and a tired look in his eyes, but he always made time to talk to us about his day, even if it was just for a few minutes. My mother, on the other hand, would come home with a mop in hand, still cleaning even after she got home. I remember her telling me that she felt proud when she saw the kids at the school smiling after she had finished her work. Both of them had a strong work ethic, and they always put our needs first, even when it meant working extra hours or sacrificing their own comfort. Their jobs may not have been glamorous, but they taught me the importance of hard work, responsibility, and dedication—values that I carry with me to this day.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Cynthia Mendoca: My father worked at a small, family-owned garage that serviced cars for the local community, and my mother worked at a public school that served students from all over the town. The garage was run by my uncle, who had been in the business for years, and my father was one of the main mechanics there. He would diagnose car problems, perform repairs, and even teach me a few things about engines when I was older. The school my mother worked at was a middle school, and her job involved cleaning classrooms, restrooms, and common areas, as well as helping with special events and ensuring the school was a safe and welcoming place for students. She would often tell me how important it was to take pride in her work, even if it wasn't always easy. Both of them were part of the same community, and their jobs were deeply tied to the people around them. I remember my father fixing cars for neighbors who couldn't afford much, and my mother cleaning the school gym before big events so the kids could have a good experience. Their work wasn't just about money—it was about helping others and contributing to the life of the town in their own way. That's something I've always admired about them, and it's one of the reasons I wanted to build a life that values service and community, just like they did.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Cynthia Mendoca: Looking a few years ahead, I hope that my family continues to grow stronger together, even as life keeps changing. I hope that Lina finds the right path for her future, whether it's in the U.S. or if she decides to visit Lithuania, and that Jonas stays curious and kind, just like he is now. I also hope that my knee pain becomes less of a concern and that I can keep up with the kids on their adventures, whether it's a hike in the woods or a long walk along the waterfront. I'd love to see us take that family trip back to Lithuania that we've been talking about for so long—it's something I know my parents would love to see, and it would mean a lot to me to share that experience with my children. I also hope that I can continue to grow in my job, maybe take on more leadership responsibilities or even mentor someone else the way I was mentored when I first started out. But above all, I hope that we keep finding joy in the little things—the smell of a Lithuanian meal cooking, the sound of my kids laughing, and the quiet moments with my husband when the world feels just right. Life has been a journey, and I'm grateful for every step we've taken so far.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Cynthia Mendoca: What I value the most in my life is the sense of connection—whether it's with my family, my heritage, or the community I've built here in Greenwich. I value the love and support of my husband and children, the traditions we carry from Lithuania, and the friendships that have helped me navigate life in a new country. I also value the opportunities I've been given, like the education that opened doors for me and the job that allows me to support my family. But above all, I value the little moments—the laughter around the dinner table, the sound of my kids speaking Lithuanian, the quiet evenings with my husband where we don't need to say much to know we're together. Life has its challenges, but these things ground me and remind me of what truly matters.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how much my financial stability, work schedule, and relationships at work contribute to my sense of balance and purpose. Talking about our household income and expenses reminded me of how far we've come as a family, and how important it is to be mindful of our financial choices while still enjoying the life we've built here. Describing my job, the benefits it provides, and the relationships I've formed with my manager and coworkers brought back memories of how I've grown professionally over the past six years. It also made me appreciate the flexibility my job offers, which allows me to manage my health, family responsibilities, and career goals. These questions helped me see how interconnected my work life and personal life are, and how much I value the stability and support that come with both.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection and gratitude. It reminded me of how far I've come—from growing up in Lithuania, adjusting to life in a new country, to building a stable and meaningful life here in Connecticut with my family. It also made me appreciate the support I've received along the way, from my parents, my high school principal, my husband, my friends, and even the community around me. Talking about my challenges, like managing my health and balancing work and family, reminded me of the strength I've found in small, everyday moments—like cooking Lithuanian meals, spending time with my kids, or simply being present in the quiet moments with my husband. This process has helped me see how much I've grown, not just as a professional, but as a mother, a wife, and a person rooted in both my heritage and my new home. I'm grateful for every step of the way, and I'm excited to see what the future holds for my family and me.
